TITLE: Petty Corruption Rife in Ethiopia
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (90%); TAX AUTHORITIES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); TAXES & TAXATION (89%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (89%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (89%); ETHICS (78%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (78%); RESEARCH REPORTS (78%); TAX LAW (77%); ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS (77%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (77%); COMPANY STRATEGY (76%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (74%); TAX AUDITS (72%); ELECTRIC POWER INDUSTRY (71%); SEWERAGE SYSTEMS (69%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS SECTOR PERFORMANCE (69%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (69%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES (69%); HOTELS & MOTELS (65%); LICENSES & PERMITS (64%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (60%); JUDGES (50%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: The first draft of the World Bank sponsored corruption study comes out pointing fingers at petty corruption in various government institutions, while playing down the impact of grand corruption. The power, tax, investment and transport sectors have been identified as having the highest level of corruption, according to a draft finding by a study under the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC). Employees of the Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation (EEPCo) have been identified by the study as being frontrunners in asking for unofficial payments, with an average of 10 bribe requests for a single respondent in the study. The EEPCo is also the organisation with the highest average number of foreign companies seeking its services. Traffic police, on the other hand, have asked more of the respondents for bribes than any of the entities surveyed, according to the report. The draft report, which included the responses of 350 foreign investors, took two and half months to produce. The final report is expected to be released a month after the World Bank approves its finalisation according to the guidelines. "Around 16.6pc of the respondents reported a total count of 370 requests with an average of six bribe demands per respondent," said the draft study released on Thursday, January 25, 2014, at the Hilton Hotel, under the title "Perception of the Level of Corruption by Foreign Investors in Ethiopia". Six percent of the respondents also reported that employees of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA) had asked them for money- a total count of 54 times for customs licenses and 49 times for tax inspection. The findings of the draft study, nevertheless, indicated that grand corruption is not a threat to Ethiopia, as none of the respondents reported confronting it. "Petty corruptions exist in almost every office," said Ameha Diana, director general of Selam Development Consultants Plc, which conducted the survey. "With only some institutions standing out in level of corruption, Ethiopia is freer than several other countries as far as corruption is concerned." Judges and court officials, employees of standards and safety offices, those in the water and sewerage agency and the state telecommunications company, ethio telecom, have also been identified as asking for bribes. Employees involved with customs and trade licenses, land acquisition, licensing authorities and tax agencies, as well as government procurement have not been immune to allegations of bribery. The results reveal that employees in these agencies are collecting bribe money ranging from 5,000 to 7,000 Br. "These employees can get paid a maximum bribe of 20,000 to 50,000 Br," the draft study said. "The Commission's strategic focus areas are taxation and revenue collection, the justice sector, procurement in major infrastructural projects, land administration and financial management," Wedo Atto, the deputy Commissioner, said in his opening remark at the launching of the draft study. Back in 2012, the second nationwide corruption survey, which was commissioned by the Commission and conducted by a Tanzanian-based US company, Kilimanjaro International Corporation (KIC), disclosed that a considerable number of the public had to make extra payments in the form of gratification to public institutions.. The judiciary, law enforcement community, municipalities and the ERCA were identified as the places most people perceived as being prone to corruption and inefficient public service delivery, according to that survey. The Commission, nevertheless, wants more than one research to point to similar problems before it takes any measures, says Berhanu Assefa, Director of Ethics Education & Communication Affairs. The World Bank (WB), Department for International Development (DFID), Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands and the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) collaborated with the FEACC in conducting the latest survey.

TITLE: High Profile Corruption Case - Prosecutor's Three-Month Extension Request Reduced to Just One
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (91%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); LAWYERS (89%); INSPECTIONS (89%); CRIMINAL DEFENSES (89%); ETHICS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); TAX FRAUD (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); TAX ENFORCEMENT (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); TAX AUTHORITIES (76%); TAXES & TAXATION (73%); FREIGHT BROKERS & FORWARDERS (50%) Ethiopia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: The case has been ongoing since last May and has seen many high profile names imprisoned throughout Defence lawyers for top federal officials accused of corruption rested their case this week, and the court gave prosecutors one month to rebut the arguments. The Federal High Court's 15th Criminal Bench has adjourned the high-profile corruption charges against Melaku Fenta - former director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA), and others, until March 18, 2014. This decision came following the prosecutors' request for more time to review the statement of defence. Senior ERCA officials were accused of relaxing the inspection procedures for undue benefits, by using the mutually beneficial relationships they established with high profile businessmen. The charge specifically mentioned the personal connections of Nega G. Egziabhere of Netsa Trading Plc, and Gebrewahed W. Giorgis, the-then deputy to Melaku in the Law Enforcement Division of the ERCA, as well as Ketema Kebede of K.K Plc, with Melaku. Melaku and Gebrewahed were also charged with violating a law that instituted impromptu inspections at the ERCA's Adama Branch, after a study revealed that the customs clearance system in that branch was looser than Kaliti and thus preferred by alleged tax evaders. The study was conducted to investigate why the Kaliti Customs Office was producing low revenues. This, the charge says, has made corrupt practices prevalent. Other charges were made, predominantly against customs officials from the ERCA's Adama Branch and Modjo Dry Port and Terminal, freight-forwarders and their family members. During the court session held on Monday, February 17, 2014, 12 defendants presented a statement of defence. They included Melaku; Gebrewahed; Belachew Beyene, former Audit Directorate director; Markneh Alemayehu, deputy prosecutor; Eshetu Giref of the Kality Branch of the ERCA;Haimanot Tesfay (Col.), Gebrewahad's wife;Fitsum G. Medihn, a businessman; Amogne Tagele, former director of the ERCA's Adama Branch Office;Tigabu Gidey, who used to work in the Tax Collection Department of the ERCA's Adama Branch; Semere Nigusse, Customs Inspection officer at the Modjo Dry Port; Mareshet Tesfaye, of MD Transit Plc and Woldesellasie W. Michael, a senior national security advisor. The Prosecutors from the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC), who requested a three month period to respond to bulky written objections filed by these and other defendants - totalling 66 charged under three separate files - drew murmurs of objection from the courtroom. The prosecutors' request was objected to by attorneys of the defendants, who argued that three months was too lengthy and would hamper the interests of their clients who remain in custody. The attorneys argued that the Commission, as an institution, could deploy more staff to review the statement of defence in a shorter period of time. The Court reduced the prosecutors' request to one month. It also allowed the attorneys of Ketema and K.K Plc to make corrections to the statement of defence they submitted during the previous session. Fikru Maru (MD), who runs Addis Cardiac Hospital, was not present in the court due to illness. In May 2013, a joint operation by law enforcement agencies made a round of arrests of senior government officials and prominent businessmen suspected of wrongdoings in relation to tax. During the lengthy investigation period, suspects have remained in custody without bail, except for those the Commission released itself. Most of the detainees have been kept at the Akaki (including Melaku and Gebrewahed) and Kilinto prison facilities.

TITLE: Federal High Court Presides Over Statements in High Profile Corruption Case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); TAX AUTHORITIES (89%); INSPECTIONS (89%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (89%); TAX LAW (78%); CRIMINAL DEFENSES (78%); JUDGES (78%); LITIGATION (78%); ETHICS (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); TAX ENFORCEMENT (77%); TAX FRAUD (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); LAWYERS (75%); SUITS & CLAIMS (73%); TAXES & TAXATION (70%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: The rebuttals to the defence have been submitted in soft copy to reduce the time spent presiding over them The Federal High Court's 15th Criminal Bench has adjourned the high profile corruption case against Melaku Fenta - former director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority - et al to April 24, 2014. This is in order to decide over the statement of defence submitted by defendants and the prosecutors' rebuttal to the statements. On Tuesday, March 18, 2014, prosecutors from the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC) submitted rebuttals to the statements of defence presented by defence lawyers for top federal officials and high-profile business people accused of corruption on February 17, 2014, and previous court sessions. Tuesday's session came after the Court gave prosecutors one month to rebut the arguments. The Commission's prosecutors came up with the rebuttals in written form. The presiding judge asked the prosecutors to submit the rebuttals in soft copy, citing two reasons. One of these has to do with reviewing the rebuttals in a shorter period of time. The judge also said that submitting the rebuttals in soft copy makes it possible to convert to Braille, because one of the defendants is blind. Prosecutors of the Commission filed the charge to the Court on Melaku Fenta and the other 66 defendants under three separate charge files. Following this, 12 defendants submitted statements of defence in a written document on February 17, 2014, while the remaining defendants had submitted them during previous court sessions. Those who submitted statements of defence on February 17 included Melaku; Gebrewahed W. Giorgis, the-then deputy to Melaku in the Law Enforcement Division of the ERCA; Belachew Beyene, former Audit Directorate director; Markneh Alemayehu, deputy prosecutor; Eshetu Giref of the Kality Branch of the ERCA; Haimanot Tesfay (Col.), Gebrewahed's wife; Fitsum G. Medihn, a businessman; Amogne Tagele, former director of the ERCA's Adama Branch Office; Tigabu Gidey, who used to work in the Tax Collection Department of the ERCA's Adama Branch; Semere Nigusse, Customs Inspection officer at the Modjo Dry Port; Mareshet Tesfaye, of MD Transit Plc and Woldesellasie W. Michael, a senior national security advisor. Melaku and Gebrewahed were charged with transgressing a law that instituted sudden inspections at the ERCA's Adama Branch, the clearance system of which, according to a study conducted to investigate why the Kaliti Customs Office was fetching minimal revenues, was looser than Kaliti and thus preferred by alleged tax evaders. The two tax officials were also charged with loosening the inspection procedures to get excessive benefits, by using the mutually beneficial relationships they established with high profile businessmen. The charge specifically cited personal connections between Gebrewahed and Nega G. Egziabhere of Netsa Trading Plc, as well as Ketema Kebede of K.K Plc with Melaku. Charges were also filed against customs officials from the ERCA's Adama Branch and Modjo Dry Port and Terminal, freight-forwarders and their family members. The attorneys of K.K Plc and Ketema Kebede claimed that news reports about the court sessions by the state-owned Ethiopian Radio & Television Agency (ERTA) were biased and defamed their clients. The presiding judge replied, however, that the Court has already passed a decision on this same claim previously. The judge told the attorneys to go back and refer to the decisions. The attorney of Fitsum Gebremedhin, a merchant who was charged with tax fraud and corruption, asked the Court to release his client on bail. The judge asked him why the request came at this time, saying that the right time to ask for bail right was during previous court sessions. The attorney replied that the request for bail rights came at this time following the amendment made by the prosecutor to the original charges against his client. The attorney argued that his client should be released on bail since the prosecutor cancelled the charge of corruption during the amendment. "The punishment for the remaining charge against my client may not exceed 10 years," he argued. The judge said they will give him a response to his request by the next session, on April 24, 2014. According to the Revised Anti-Corruption Special Procedure & Rules of Evidence Proclamation of 2005, a person arrested for a corruption offence punishable by more than 10 years may not be released on bail. Senior government officials and prominent business people suspected of offences in relation to tax were arrested in May 2013 following a joint operation by law enforcement agencies.

TITLE: Three Former Senior Land Officials Freed From Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (90%); VERDICTS (89%); NATURAL RESOURCES (89%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (75%); SUITS & CLAIMS (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); CONSTRUCTION (73%); LAND LEASES (73%); RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION (73%); BUILDING PERMITS (68%); HOTELS & MOTELS (55%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A majority vote by judges on Tuesday April 28, 2014, have found not guilty former Addis Abeba land deputy, Kassim Fite, and two of his subordinates from corruption charges leveled against them by the Federal Ethics & Anti Corruption Commission (FEACC) over a 433 sqm plot of land. A third defendant in the case will still face charges. The Commission sued Kassim, who was deputy head of the Addis Ababa Land Development and Administration office, and three others, claiming that they had misused their power to snatch away the plot from Girma Afewerk (Eng) and give it to Yohannes Derseh, owner of the Alexandria Hotel, for expansion. The charge claims that Kassim, supported by wrong legal advise to the former land management board from the second defendant Tesfaye Zemdekun, who was an expert at Addis Abeba Justice Bureau, gave the land to Yohannes. The third defendant Gebreyesus Kidane, director of Construction Permits during the time, allegedly failed to mention that Girma, after initially losing the land, had asked again to get it back for investment purposes, and the fourth defendant, Bekele Gebre, who was head of the Land Bank & Transfer Office, was also an accomplice in the wrong decision of the board. The dismissed charges also held the defendants responsible for 342,500 Br in damages for construction inputs, which Girma had used on the land, when it was taken from him. Two of the three judges of the Federal High Court's First Criminal Bench, Getachew Yirga, Zewditu Tafesse, and Yosef Kiros, ruled that only Tesfaye had to defend the charges against him, while they voted to let Kassim and the other two walk free, a decision to which Judge GetachewYirga did not agree. "The charge against Kassim, Gebreyesus and Bekele should not be dropped; they should defend the charges with Tesfaye, because the prosecutor's documents and witnesses implicate them in the crime," Getachew wrote in his ruling. Tesfaye, who, by majority vote, will be the sole defendant, will defend the charges against him starting from the next appointment, May 7, 2014. He is eligible a bail of 5,000 Br. The plot in question is in Bole District Woreda 3, Kebelle 19. It used to have three residential houses on a total of 500 sqm plot. When Girma first got the land, he was given a temporary plan in 2010 for 433 sqm, and he had to build houses for the residents there in alternative plots arranged by the city. But later the land management office annulled Girma's plan some time before the board decision to lease the land to Yohannes after he paid 571,000 Br for the 433 sqm plot of land in 2012. The board decided to pass the land to Yohannes, the prosecutor claimed, because Bekele and Gebreyesus had failed to inform the board that Girma had wanted the land for investment. The three judge sruled that the defendants should not be sued as the board's decision to lease the land to Yohannes had come after Girma's plan was annulled, as a result of which his request to invest on the land could not be an essential evidence for the charge. Yohannes Derseh, owner of the Alexandria Hotel, said his application to expand on the plot had been waiting 10 years before he got the permission. Girma would not comment, saying he had no knowledge of the Court's decision.

TITLE: 'Salary Increase Will Curb Police Corruption' - Police Media Boss
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); PRESS CONFERENCES (73%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Head of Police Media and spokesman has told Concord Times in an exclusive interview that the new salary increase by the government "will go a long way in curbing corruption within the police", but urged the government to do more by ensuring their salary is competitive with other police forces in the sub-region. Comparatively, according to Assistant Superintendent Ibrahim Samura, the Sierra Leone Police are still not better paid, considering what their counterparts in the sub-region are receiving as take-home-pay. "Police officers in Ghana are paid about US$800 [a month], while the Sierra Leone Police personnel are receiving far less than that," he said. The Sierra Leone Police force has, in various reports, been classed as the most corruption institution in the country. A 2008 Public Perception Survey report published by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) rated the police as 85 percent corrupt. The report was, however, vehemently challenged by the Inspector General of Police, Francis Munu, at a press conference just days after the ranking was released by the country's anti-graft commission. Also, some rank and file members within the police argued that they are poorly paid and that most of them are tempted to receive bribes so as to meet their family needs. Previously, most police constables were receiving below US$100 as monthly salary. Prior to the 2012 elections, the situation became much better as each police officer started receiving a bag of rice in addition to their monthly salaries. As at present, the least police officer is receiving above US$100, reflecting the new salary increase by the government for all public workers. "We heartily appreciate the new increase and we believe such would go a long way in curbing corruption within the police," said ASP Samura.

TITLE: Mayor, MPs Corruption Dramaacc Urged to Investigate
BYLINE: Mohamed Massaquoi, Jariatu Bangura and Samuel J. Kargbo
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); MAYORS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BUDGETS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); APPROPRIATIONS (90%); CITIES (78%); APPROVALS (75%); BUDGET PROPOSALS (75%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: It was real drama yesterday at Committee Room No.1 in the Sierra Leone House of Parliament when the Mayor of the Kenema City Council, Joseph Samba Keifala, the Chief Administrator Daniel Sahr Momoh, his deputy Alie Fofanah and Finance Officer David Kallon, were all summoned by Parliament to substantiate corruption allegations made against members of the Sub-Appropriation Committee. It could be recalled that Mayor Keifala on Tuesday 16 December, during the popular 'Good Morning Salone' radio programme aired on FM 98.1, claimed that he had been reliably informed by the Deputy Chief Administrator that the council's annual budget for 2015 would not be approved by the committee on the ground that they had failed to give a bribe to members of the committee. This warranted the invitation of the Mayor and team to prove their allegations. The committee room was full to capacity with parliamentarians, journalists, heads of institutions, civil society representatives and members of the public all attending the hearing on a matter that has generated so much public interest since the claim by the Mayor that some MPs had requested for Le20 million before his council's budget will be approved. Deputy Chief Administrator Fofanah informed the panel of MPs that indeed some members of the Sub-Appropriation Committee did request from them a bribe, for which he later called the Chief Administrator and the Mayor and informed them about the development. Fofanah said he categorically told the MPs that they had no money to give out; a development he said led to the council's annual budget to be overlooked and not debated upon by the committee. "I consider this to be an unfortunate development, and I had to communicate back immediately as I was representing my Chief Administrator," Fofanah told the panel. "We were in parliament on the 26th November 2014 alongside three other senior officials, including the Finance Officer. We were taken to an office where we met Hon. Abubakarr S.A.T. Koroma, Hon. Hassan Sheriff among other MPs. We were told that one Chairman Fofanah has negotiated on behalf of the councils, but I said to them we were not prepared for that. Because of this, we were directed to one Mr. Sannoh, the committee's clerk, to hand over our documents. I later returned to Kenema and informed the Mayor about what had transpired. The Mayor then told me there was no money to give to the committee." Fofanah said despite pleading for an adjournment, the committee refused to grant them their wish. "Usually, we do some gestures when we come to parliament," he revealed. In his statement, the Majority Leader of Parliament, Hon. Ibrahim Bundu, who chaired the panel, said over 128 ministries, departments and agencies have already presented their budgets without any hindrance, noting that they have the power to withhold budgets if there was no proper accountability. "The media should serve as a responsible gatekeeper but the manner in which the station [98.1 FM] handled the program was unprofessional," blasted Hon. Bundu. "Article 9 of the IMC Act stipulates that live phone-in programs must be managed in such a way that they are not used to incite violence and public disorder. This matter will be handed over to the Anti-Corruption Commission for further investigation," he concluded.

TITLE: 'Corruption' Slowed Ebola Response
SUBJECT: EBOLA VIRUS DISEASE (95%); TROPICAL DISEASES (91%); EMERGENCY VEHICLES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (89%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); AUDITS (89%); VIRUSES (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); ACCOUNTING (77%); EXECUTIVES (72%); INDICTMENTS (69%); MARINE & WATERWAY CONSTRUCTION (69%); PUBLIC CONTRACTS LAW (67%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (65%); AIR FARES (63%) Sierra Leone; Ebola; Corruption
TEXT: Monies set aside for the purpose of combating the Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone may have been used for unintended purposes, thereby slowing the government's response to eradicate the virus, notes a report on the audit of the management of the Ebola funds laid on the table of Parliament yesterday by the deputy Speaker of the House, Hon. Chernor Maju Bah. The report, titled "Audit of the Management of the Ebola Funds", covers the period between May and October 2014. Among the plethora of revelations made by Audit Service Sierra Leone (ASSL) is the Ministry of Health and Sanitation's alleged failure to produce any documentation for contract agreements that amounted to Le17 billion (including Le12.7 billion for the purchase of 50 vehicles and ambulances, and Le2.7 billion for the construction of the Port Loko Treatment Centre) - all to aid the fight against the dreaded Ebola virus. "There was a complete disregard for the law on public procurement in an emergency situation. For instance, contracts were entered into without any clear guidelines on the specification of items required," the report discloses. "Furthermore, contracts were badly drawn up as if to allow for additional costs to be incurred thereby preventing a transparent, competitive and cost effective procurement." The ASSL report further highlights that the contract in respect of the purchase of 20 ambulances for a contract sum of US$1,050,000 was inappropriately entered into "as specific areas relating to the inspection, transportation and delivery of the ambulances were excluded in the Special Conditions of the contract". Consequently, the report notes, additional costs of $60,590 and Le39,330,000 were incurred in respect of air freight, daily subsistence allowance and airfare for the ambulances bought by the Ministry of Health and Sanitation. In addition, contracts worth over Le1 billion in respect of food for quarantined homes were awarded to various suppliers without regard to the provisions of the procurement regulation in relation to procurement in an emergency, it adds. The ASSL audit team further found that payments were made to the Member of Parliament for Constituency 93 in Goderich to carry out sensitisation activities even though an amount had earlier been paid to all seating members of parliament for similar activities. Also, the report indicts civil society activist and Executive Director of Health For All Coalition (HFAC), Charles Mambu, whose organisation was said to have been loaned the sum of Le421,800,000 for scaling up of the response to the Ebola fight. The auditors were however concerned that the said loaned amount was made in the name of Charles Mambu instead of HFAC, the organisation which he represents. "In addition, the loan was not documented and the repayment terms were not agreed between the ministry and HFAC," the report indicates. To this, the report recommends that the Permanent Secretary and the Director of Financial Resources in the Ministry of Health provide adequate explanation for this discrepancy within seven days of the receipt of the report. The ministry, it admonishes, should also ensure that it desists from such practices and that all further payments be addressed in the name of the beneficiary organisations and not individuals. "The Permanent Secretary should also submit to the Audit Service within seven (7) days an approved repayment terms and conditions for the recovery of the loan given to the Health for All Coalition for audit inspection; and also implement the necessary measures to recover the funds within the shortest possible time," ASSL demands.

TITLE: ACC, NMO Campaign Against Ebola and Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); TROPICAL DISEASES (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); EBOLA VIRUS DISEASE (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); VIRUSES (71%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (68%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (56%) Sierra Leone; Ebola; Corruption
TEXT: Some two hundred men and women of the National Marketing Organization (NMO) on Saturday 11th April joined the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in an end Ebola and anti- corruption campaign across major markets in Freetown. The "End Ebola and Corruption Campaign" was a sensitization exercise to educate the public, especially marketers, on the dangers of Ebola and corruption and the benefits of eradicating both diseases. Addressing the campaigners at the entrance of the Vine Memorial Secondary School, Congo Cross, the ACC Deputy Commissioner, Shollay Davies, commended NMO for partnering with the commission and stressed the significance of the campaign as Sierra Leone grapples with the countdown to ending the Ebola virus disease. Mr. Davies entreated the marketers to disseminate anti-Ebola and anti-corruption messages as buyers and sellers would better understand information from them. He highlighted key messages that would constitute the campaign notably: the community has power to stop Ebola; safe and dignified burial; only you and I can say no to Ebola; and celebrate survivors. He assured the marketers and the general public of the commission's "undiluted support" to crack down on corruption in the fight against Ebola in the country. Earlier, the Director of Public Education and Outreach Department, Koloneh Sankoh, admonished the marketers to observe the preventive measures of hand washing and 'no body contact' as they raise awareness on Ebola. She underscored the commission's resolve to working with civil society groups to eradicate corruption in all its forms. Buyers and sellers in the Western Urban and Rural Areas benefited from anti-corruption and anti-Ebola messages at different moments of the tour, which were inscribed on placards and information, education and communication materials distributed as well.

TITLE: Recovering From Corruption Crackdown [analysis]
SUBJECT: TAXES & TAXATION (91%); INDICTMENTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (90%); TAX LAW (89%); TAX AUTHORITIES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); TAX REFORM (72%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: Beker Shale is Director General of Ethiopian Revenues and Customs Authority (ERCA.) Beker assumed the position after the ex-director general, Melaku Fenta, and his deputy, Gebrewahid Woldegiorgis, were indicted with corruption charges for which they are standing trial currently. Since then, Beker has been focused on house-clearing activities and serious evaluation processes. In the nine month the authority identified that corruption has been its primary concern and in the process some 122 employees were given their marching orders while many others were given stern warnings and/or reassignments. Recently, the authority held its third countrywide tax conference where it met taxpayers mainly from the business community. At the conference the authority announced that it is in the process of transformation. Birhanu Fekade of The Reporter sat down with the director to expound on this new change and transformation. Excerpts: The Reporter: Recently you held the third countrywide tax conference. A conference aimed at raising stakeholders' awareness about the tax reform you are undertaking and some of the challenges the tax system is facing. But you have been doing the some for years now, what is so different this time? Beker Shale: To evaluate the changes in this sector, I prefer to look at it from two different perspectives. Most of the time, challenges are springboards to finding solutions. So the first step is to identify the strong and weak sides of the main executing body, the Revenues and Customs Authority. Hence, the past nine months were mainly dedicated to trainings and changing the mindsets. In that, we have to reach an understanding as to what extent the complaint of the taxpayer is true and how we can fix them. We tried to form consensus on the matter with personnel at all levels. I do not know how one would perceive change and judge if change has come to the tax system for instance. But this much I know, now authority's personnel at all levels are ready to solve these problems. The other side of the story is our engagement with the taxpayer. We tried to access taxpayers through our regional, Addis Ababa and federal levels. This time, we tried to make the communication between the taxpayer and the tax collector that of a relationship of equals so that there is transparency in our communication. Apart from that, we have a regular schedule to meet with the taxpayer and learn about their problems. As a direct outcome to this, we have also taken steps to reform some parts of our system that have proven to be a problem for the taxpayers. Especially, issues in relation to tax grievances and the work of the technical committee, which remained a long and protracted process until recently, is set to be handled by the law and the law only. On the other hand, we also have launched customs evaluation software. This new software is expected to solve some of the problems in relation to customs evaluation. We are also speeding up our one-stop-shop project. Besides, we have taken some steps to give solution to some of the problems that have been rolling for sometime, issues including the dividend tax directive and those with tour and travel companies. So, I think, if these efforts are strengthened, we would see real changes soon. Recently, investigation by the auditor general found out that out of the 79 thousand cash register machines in the tax system, only 12 thousand send their reports regularly, while some 15 thousand of these machines have no link to the tax system whatsoever. What was that all about? I do not have the details of the auditors general report. But, as far as the cash register machines are concerned, the reach seems to be expanding by day. Previously, taxpayers had doubts about the machine. This was because of the speculation that the machines are introduced to monitor each and every financial activity of businesses. So, this had bad bearings on the speed with which the machines were introduced into the tax system. Later on, the members of the business community started to realize that using the machines would actually save them from embezzlement and can help develop trust in the tax system. However, we also understand that not all machines are working properly. This is mainly due to two reasons. One is the network problem; some of the machines are not sending proper reports because of our own network problem. Now, we are following up on such issues and are trying to give quick fixes whenever possible. There are also some who have the intention of hiding their tax returns. Some of them also argue that they have lost the machines; the problems are diverse. Hence, one can see that many machines are not sending proper reports to the central database. I hope we will have the auditor general's report very soon. And then we can take corrective measures to improve on identified issues. At the moment, the tax authority is one of the most feared institutions in the country. You have resources at your disposal including your own intelligence, monitoring and follow teams and like to enforce tax law. However, you still could not stop those who are printing and using illegal VAT receipts right in the middle of the capital city. What does that say about you? By the way, fear of law enforcement by itself cannot ensure compliance. There is a big difference between fearing the law and respecting the law. All over the world, criminals do what they do knowing what the legal consequence is going to be. By the same token, tax fraud is also not about fearing the law enforcement. It is a crime. It is committed in defiance of law and its percussions. This tells you that enforcement can never guarantee compliance of tax obligations. Rather what works is awareness and consensus building around tax; and why citizens pay taxes. Everyone loves their country, so taxpayers should be aware that tax evasion is crime against one's own people and its growth and progress. By taking measures, one cannot teach society to execute its tax obligations. Nevertheless, those who are found in clear violation of laws should be punished according to the law. As tax is something that society in general stands to benefit from, I think, the people should stand side-by-side with the tax authority to fight this crime. Talking about tax compliance, Mercato has been one problem area that the tax authority identified. And you have been focused on Mercato for quite some time now. Nevertheless, it still is the most problematic area of all, why is that? Mercato is the biggest open market in Ethiopia where some of the prominent wholesalers and distributers are located. Historically, it was a very concentrated market. This concentration is declining to some extent now. For ages Mercato handled large volumes of trade, which has more of a shadow market nature. Although not all, there are some whose main line of business is distributing contraband items in the market. In doing so, they are distorting the market. Their impact extends to the regional markets; of course they have partners in regionals who will assist them in distorting the market. After we kick started the Mercato project, a number of businesses joined the taxation system; a number of them registered for VAT, Turnover taxes since then. However, we cannot say this is a structural change since the problem still exists. For instance, those under the formal tax system suffer as they engage in transaction with those outside of the tax system. This is exhibited specially in the regional markets. The businessmen in regional market are ready to expose them. At any rate, we should put an end to the deep-rooted problems of Mercato. Another issue is with the discipline of your employees. Previously, the authority itself admitted that it has been challenged with corruption and fraud. Employing different forgery tactics, the employees have embezzled a lot of money in the past, and now the new college graduates you are recruiting are rumored to have raised the bribe money. So, where is the change that you speak of? Although I cannot argue that such problems do not exist. I have to admit that I do not have the information about what you are talking about. Yes, we have a discipline problem that we to have deal with. And, if there are individuals who are engaged in such activities like forging documents, the society should come forward and expose them. What we can do is that when the taxpayer faces such problems they can approach the tax authority and ask for documentations to be verified. I think corrupt employees of the tax authority can only intimidate those taxpayers who are not legal themselves. The taxpayer should not be intimidated that easily since there are ways to get second opinions about the matter at hand. But, I cannot accept your assertion that new university graduates hired by the authority are generally corrupt. There are a lot of fresh graduate recruits who are well-behaved and work diligently for their country. At the same time, there are also some who come with a rent-seeking attitude; or get infected with one after joining. But, I cannot think it is that big of a deal since as long as the awareness is there both the taxpayer and the other workers would expose them. Still talking about discipline, we also heard that around Mercato, some of your monitoring and follow up personnel even have informal salary offers and some of them also serve as critical informants to those who pay them a surprise tax audit. And/or surprise visit of tax authority personnel. How do you see this? Yes, we have also received such information repeatedly. We have also heard that there are brokers who would create the link between the tax personnel and the taxpayer. Here what has to be understood is that it is the rent-seeking nature in the business community that will give our personnel the chance to prosper from such activities. You see, it is partly due to problems among the business community that helps. These businesses might have some illegal activities that they do not want people to discover. The business community has to take them down off his/her shoulder by exposing them to the authority. But, it is also important to understand that there are tax personnel who do their job diligently. I am in no way trying to intimidate those personnel that go out to do their monitoring job. Nevertheless, there are some we are following either in secrecy or openly. These days the capital flight is becoming a problem for most African countries. Experts accuse big multinational companies of exaggerating prices and flying with billions of dollars; Ethiopia is among them. What are you doing to withstand this pressure? I have a hard time buying that Ethiopia is loosing billions of dollars to capital flight and illicit financial transaction. Maybe it could be a report that is outdated. It is very difficult to verify such reports. However, we do have controlling mechanisms to monitor financial activities, financial resources either going out or coming into the country. We try to monitor the activities at our various checkpoints. Thus far, we have not come across such data. For instance, over invoicing is one mechanism by which capital can be... Well, you can address this question to the responsible authorities like the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED) or the National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE); we do not have such information or data. Last budget year, you succeeded in collecting some 107 billion birr, how is your performance going for the current budget year? As per our nine-month performance, especially in terms of what has to be transferred to MoFED, we have met 97 percent of our target. For Addis Ababa as well, it is somewhere around 89 percent. But, this is only what the Addis Ababa branch has collected, when we add what the federal collects and channels to the city, the target is already met. Hence, I can say that our nine-month performance was encouraging; it will not be too hard to meet 100 percent of our target in the remaining time.

TITLE: Rooting Out Corruption
SUBJECT: BUDGETS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); ANNUAL REPORTS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); APPROVALS (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (77%); EMBEZZLEMENT (74%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (74%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (69%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (65%); URBAN TRANSIT SYSTEMS (64%); TARIFFS & DUTIES (50%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Some 178.5 birr (close to USD 9 billion) was approved by the House of Peoples' Representatives as federal government expenditure for the budget year. As the closing year of the Government of Ethiopia's 5-year Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP) during which the economic growth recorded over the past decade is expected to be consolidated, much needs to be done in order to tackle the problems that have rolled over the years and stand in the way of the achievement of the GTP. The new fiscal year must see an all-out effort by the government to eradicate bad governance and corruption, scourges which are a source of widespread public discontent. Unless government structures at all levels rid themselves of bad governance, corruption and mismanagement, it would be impossible to utilize properly the huge budget allocated for the federal government. Though the government has vowed repeatedly to deal with the causes to which the grievances widely expressed by the public are attributed, the problems are still pervasive. Hence, any and all practices of public officials and servants which advance their selfish interest at the expense of the public require prompt response by all concerned. The egregious acts committed by organized elements both within the government and outside are preventing the delivery of services efficiently and in compliance with quality standards. There exist patently grave problems in the areas of the issuance and renewal of trade license and certificate of competence; the assessment and payment of tax and customs duty; the provisioning of land and other municipal services; the availability and quality of telecom, power, water and mass transit services; the miscarriage of justice at the hands of the lowest administrative units to the highest organs of the judiciary, etc. These manifestations of bad governance not only actively harm the national and public interest but also lead to disenfranchisement and thereby the erosion of political capital. As such they require urgent action on the part of all stakeholders. The rampant corruption besetting the country is another serious challenge. Without prejudice to the arrest and prosecution in 2013 of senior government officials on charges of grand corruption, the problem continues to spread like wildfire. Creating a society which abhors corruption, important as it is, is not enough to combat corruption. The anti-corruption drive under way should be ramped up so that anyone caught up in it must be brought to justice and punished to the full extent of the law. The Federal Auditor General has repeatedly stated in its annual report to Parliament that several government institutions are guilty of failing to reconcile substantial sums of money. Although it would be rash to conclude that the unreconciled money was all embezzled, the government is obliged to take firm action in the backdrop of the gaps observed in the financial management of the agencies it runs. The shoddy practices characterizing the procurement and property administration of government offices also opens the door for corruption. In fact such practices have allowed several millionaires to spring up overnight. Ethiopia badly needs a no-nonsense leadership which enforces strict oversight. After all, a bureaucracy that is mired in bad governance and corruption is incapable of administering properly the huge budget approved by lawmakers as well as implement faithfully the next phase of the GTP due to commence a year from now. Therefore, as bad governance and corruption cannot be tolerated by any country let alone a poor nation as ours, those messing up with the country and the public must be stopped by all legal means. The 2014/2015 fiscal year is a time Ethiopia will hold the fifth national elections. Given that an electorate fed up with the lack of good governance and the prevalence may very well punish the politicians running for office through its vote, the contenders have no choice but to get their acts together. As we have said time and again in Ethiopia the value given to good governance does not go beyond paying lip service to its importance. And the fight against corruption is being conducted sporadically instead of a coordinated and unbiased manner. The impact this will have on the outcome of the elections should keep awake all who take part in them. Actions which are not anchored in the interest of the public are bound to be counterproductive and come back to haunt their perpetrators. This makes it imperative for the government to put, at the start of the new fiscal year, the eradication of bad governance and corruption squarely at the forefront of the critical agendas it pursues for the year.

TITLE: Acquitted Corruption Suspect Secures Key Position in City Administration
SUBJECT: CITY GOVERNMENT (95%); CITIES (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); ACQUITTAL (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); ETHICS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT (78%); LAND USE PLANNING (78%); LAND GRANTS (78%); VERDICTS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (72%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: The former head of land administration of the Addis Ababa City Administration, Kassim Fitte, who was accused of corruption and abuse of power but was later acquitted of all charges by the Federal High Court has been given a new senior position on Mayor Diriba Kuma's team, The Reporter learnt. Along with Kassim, who is now appointed to the post of senior advisor to the mayor in infrastructure affairs, other former officials and also suspects in the same charges: Bekele Gebre and Gebreyesus Kidane were also granted a post in the city administration in tune of head of Urban Land Development and Management Office and Land Granting Process Officer. Three of the former officials were charged by the Federal Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission in connection with 500 square meters of land in Woreda 17 and 19, the charges investigators had instituted explained. The court heard, before reaching the verdict, that the suspects were accused of granting a title deed to the plot of land in question, which was in fact registered under the ownership of Girma Afework (Eng.), to a third party: Yohannes Derseh. The former head of Land Administration and Development Office of the Addis Ababa City Administration, Kassim, has been on trial for a year until the Federal High Court, Second Criminal Bench released him scot-free a few months ago. Kassim was under custody after his immunity was revoked last year by the House of Peoples' Representatives, after being accused of involvement in corruption activities. Kassim was reportedly said to have fled abroad two days after his immunity was revoked. However, police detained him immediately after he came back to Addis Ababa. Later, the Federal Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission's investigators brought him before the Federal High Court. It is also to be recalled that the investigators had claimed that the suspects had allegedly granted the land without a legal basis while he knew that the owner of the land had all the legal documents and the title deed, recognized by the Addis Ababa City Administration and by the city's First Instance Court.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption - a Quest for Justice
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); ETHICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); INDICTMENTS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); AGENCY RULEMAKING (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (75%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (67%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: As part of a series of wide civil service reforms, the Federal Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC) was established in 2001 whose powers are defined in the revised Proclamation 433 of 2005. The commission's mandate is only at the federal level, which includes the federal cities of Addis Ababa and Dire Dawa. Since 2007, seven of the nine regional states have established their own anti-corruption commissions to fight and prevent corruption in their respective regions. The commission has adapted Hong Kong's three-pronged approach to fighting corruption, which incorporates investigation, prosecution and prevention/ethics education. The corruption law issued a decade ago did not allow FEACC to handle private sector's corruption crimes. It was primarily limited to corruption occurring in government organizations, and was concerned with the private sector only when there is involvement on state level corruption cases. But following the 2012 crackdown on corruption of officials including the then director general of the Ethiopian Revenues and Customs Authority (ERCA), Melaku Fenta, and his erstwhile deputy, Gebrewahid Woldegiorgis, the FEACC had announced that it was drafting a new regulation that will also enable it to investigate and indict the private sector on corruption claims. Now, two years later, the draft law has been tabled before the House of Peoples' Representatives (HPR) on November 13. The draft law immediately attracted the attention of legal experts and the private sector. It also stirred some debates particularly on the new inclusion of provision which gives the commission even mightier power with regard to corruption offenses particularly at the federal level. The new proclamation that shall mainly focus on organizations that manage public finances, such as share companies, proposes that the commission gets full access to investigate and charge private businesses that are suspected of fraudulent activities. According to the draft proclamation, in private businesses someone who uses or administers his/her own resources can use it for their own benefit or the benefit of others since that is their own right and there is no any circumstance to hold them accountable. Therefore, there is no ground to take to indict them based on the definition of corruption but they will only accountable if they are found or suspected of using the fund which is collected from the public or the resources intended for public use, violating their responsibility of administering it only, the draft reads. However, some legal experts have criticized the new provisions that are proposed for amendments. Particularly, the proposed provision that enables the commission "to withdraw, in accordance with law, investigation and charges as well as corruption cases pending in the court of law". According to experts, this makes the country's legal system questionable. The draft law, in additions to what is stipulated in the same provision, states that it has the mandate "to terminate corruption investigation or corruption charges by insuring the forfeiture of the advantage obtained from the crime". But experts did not see this sub-article in a positive way rather they describe it as something "that affects the criminal justice system". A senior official at FEAC told The Reporter than the decision to enable the commission withdrawing the investigation and charges has come after intensive discussions that help resolving corruption issues with a consensus by which the suspect to return any resources that he is believed to have taken. "This system is very important in resolving the cases by saving the cost of investigation, time and labor", he said. This is also explained in the draft bill. "Inclusion of such kinds of provisions for any organization is contradictory with the justice system as it should have been treated with the amendment of the criminal justice system," a legal expert, who requested anonymity, told The Reporter. He further suggested that the legislative body should enact a substantive law based on the country's existing legal framework. On Thursday, The Reporter's attempt to obtain comments from Ali Suleiman, commissioner of the FEACC, on the amendment was not successful. He reasoned out by saying that he has a busy schedule and is not willing to comment on the issue until he calls press conference. Still the issue is being dealt with in the parliament including the scheduled public hearing session that the House's Legal and Administration Standing committee will call as of next week. According to the draft proposal, any private company or organization who collects resources, money or property or any organization who is responsible to administer this resources collected for the benefit of the public is to be held accountable for corruption. These include like private sectors engaged in health and education sectors or those who engage in any, activities with provides service related to issuance of licenses, certification or anything related to that. "These responsibilities that are given to the private sector which would be authorized by the government might be misused for another under advantage and such kinds of acts result in causing damage on the state or public property," the document explains. Public organizations include religions organizations, politics parties, international organizations, Edir (a traditional community organization whose members assist each other during the mourning process) or other similar traditional or religious associations. Similarly, companies in the finance sector such as share companies, banks, insurance companies, money transfer agents, are also considered by the document as public organizations definition as they collected money or resources from the public. However, religious organizations, political parties, international organizations as well as micro and small enterprises, Edir and similar traditional associations are exempted from the definition to by regulated by anti-corruption in Ethiopia. While the bill propose several amendments by introducing new provisions; it also equally widens the role, responsibility and power of the commission which is responsible in implementing or enforcing the law. However, there are sorts of issues which are stated in the proposed provisions which look quite contentious and debatable. In fact, still the bill is not endorsed yet. But it is believed to be the main focuses for the Legal and Administration Standing Committee to whom the house referred the bill to. Among the contentious issues for some legal experts is the reason behind the omission of religious organizations, political parties and some enterprises like small one micro enterprise from regulation. "For micro and small enterprises like Edir, Equb and similar traditional associations, the amount of finance they mobilize and the small number of members the have does not make them a likely target for investigations. In addition, the labor, time and finance that would be spent to investigate and bring them before justice would likely be greater than the amount of money and resource that would be embezzled," according to the document. Moreover, the new bill has proposed to strengthen the commission's power over any other federal entities that have the legitimate power to investigate and institute charges regarding any corruption offense related to their respective sectors. "... no institution having prosecutorial power shall have the power to prosecute corruption offenses falling under the federal jurisdiction unless it is delegated to do so by the commission". The document explains that since there was no implementation system in the country's legislation, which can help resolves offense cases other than charging in court, it was not able to save financial, time and labor costs that is spent during investigation, trial and debating; and it has not been able to save resources that was embezzled by corruption. The Reporter has learnt that they drove this provision from the British experience. Amid the debates on the provisions, the standing committee scheduled a public hearing session to hear and collect suggestions and recommendation from the public before the draft is sent back to lawmakers for final endorsement.

TITLE: House Approves the Removal of Two Judges for Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); JUDGES (92%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (91%); APPROVALS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); BRIBERY (89%); ETHICS (78%); JAIL SENTENCING (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); SENTENCING (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (78%); SUPREME COURTS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); VERDICTS (78%); CORRECTIONS (77%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The House of Peoples' Representatives (HPR) on Tuesday has unanimously approved the removal of two federal judges for breach of disciplinary rules which resulted in conviction on corruption charges. The House has been reviewing the removal of one Federal High Court and another Federal First Instance Court judges after their case was referred to it by the Federal Judicial Administration Council. Berhanu Meshesha and Zerihun Assefa, former judges in the Federal High and Federal First Instance courts respectively, were named in the judicial administration's report presented to the HPR. The case of the two judges was being reviewed by the House's Legal, Justice and Administration Standing Committee over the last four and half months. The committee told the house that it has found the administration's request relevant to bar the former judges from their position as federal judges. The committee further said in its report that it has proved that the two judges have violated the disciplinary rule as indicated in the report submitted by the judiciary administration. The administration made a decision to revoke the two judges' appointment following their conviction on corruption charges. According to the report presented before the MPs, Berhanu had been a judge for Federal High Court since 2008 while Zerihun had been working for the Federal First Instance Court since February 1998. Berhanu is convicted of abusing his position to acquit an unnamed defendant in a criminal case he presided over after accepting a bribe, according to the administration's report. That prompted the Federal Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission to file charges against Berhanu at the Federal High Court. The Federal Supreme Court found Berhanu guilty in absentia and sentenced him to eight years in prison and a 5,000 birr fine on October 12, 2013. Berhanu fled the country before he was convicted. Meanwhile, the Commission accused the second judge, Zerihun, of receiving bribes and, later, the High Court gave him a 4-year prison term along with a 7,000 birr fine. According to the FDRE Constitution, appointment and dismissal of judges can only be effected after an approval by the country's legislative body. The judicial administration requested that the Houses of Peoples' Representatives dismiss the two judges in a letter submitted on April 14, 2014.

TITLE: Pass law to recover corruption proceeds
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATION (77%); LARCENY & THEFT (77%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (76%); POLITICS (76%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (74%)
TEXT: We must, however, not tire to tighten the noose legally against the corrupt even when they seemingly still manage to get away with it. The proposed Assets Recovery Bill might, therefore, not be the magic wand that will deal the practice a fatal blow but it will go a long way in reducing the maneuverable space for those who engage in corruption. Deputy Inspector General of Government (IGG) Mariam Wangadya has called on Parliament to expedite the passing of the Proceeds of Assets Recovery Bill, 2013 in order to enable the inspectorate seize properties of those convicted of corruption and theft of public property. With most Ugandans clearly disgusted at the level of corruption and many politicians making the fight against corruption as their campaign mantra during every election, one would imagine no urging is required to pass a law such as this which would try to make corruption less beneficial. However, it seems our political leaders are more comfortable talking about fighting corruption than actually fighting the vice. The result is that the vice has continued to grow and has now eaten up every edifice of public life. Uganda has the dubious distinction of being the most corrupt country in East Africa and holds its place among the most corrupt countries in the world. Many laws to fight corruption have been put in place over the years with minimal success. We must, however, not tire to tighten the noose legally against the corrupt even when they seemingly still manage to get away with it. The proposed Assets Recovery Bill might, therefore, not be the magic wand that will deal the practice a fatal blow but it will go a long way in reducing the maneuverable space for those who engage in corruption. But ultimately, the country will have to examine its moral outlook and weigh its ambivalence on vices such as corruption vis-viz the cost to development, human life and the future generation. And this is not just about the leaders who preside over the corruption but the ordinary Ugandans who applaud or look on simply because one of their own has also had an opportunity to steal. Hopefully, when we are sufficiently awakened morally and as the cost of corruption weighs on us individually and collectively, we will take a stand and say enough. Meantime, any law that nibbles at the vice is welcome.

TITLE: NRM regime: 28 years of primitive feudal rule, institutionalised corruption
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); TAX FRAUD (89%); CORRUPTION (85%); PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION (78%); TAXES & TAXATION (76%); BRIBERY (76%); OFFICE PROPERTY (74%); SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS (74%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (71%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (71%); RENTAL PROPERTY (70%); RADIO BROADCAST INDUSTRY (70%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (69%); COMMERCIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (69%); CONTRACT AWARDS (69%); TOURNAMENTS (69%); SPORTS AWARDS (69%); POLITICAL PARTIES (67%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (64%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (64%); OLYMPICS (64%)
TEXT: There is not a single square kilometre in Kampala where everything works fully --- street lights, drainage, piped water, roads and garbage management. At least one or more of these has a problem. In the strict sense of the word, there is no longer such a thing as the NRM. What we see passing off as the NRM is a collection of politicians, businessmen, army, intelligence and police officers, relatives and hustlers all using the name NRM to work to personal advantage. Many "NRM" MPs and Cabinet ministers have used that name as a cover to secure licences to operate private radio stations, evade taxes, run for office, and secure jobs and scholarships for their children and other relatives. President Museveni himself does not believe in the NRM but like his ministers and other officials around him must have official cover to go about his private business. Most of the president's relatives get involved in the general election campaigns and work for the re-election task forces on behalf of Museveni as their relative and benefactor, not the NRM as a national political organisation in which they see themselves as a of part. From time to time, this lack of personal conviction about what the NRM is can be seen when newspapers report that various NRM offices in Kampala and in the smaller towns have been closed because they failed to pay rent. This is the way Uganda is being run. Occasionally, such as when the Uganda Cranes is playing a crucial Africa Cup of Nations qualifying match or the athlete Stephen Kiprotich wins Olympic and World championship marathon gold medals, the appearance of patriotism and nationalist fervour is seen. However, on a day-to-day basis, Uganda as a concept does not figure much in most people's minds. They are busy attending to the practical business of trying to get by. Getting by in Uganda today largely means trying to figure out how to defraud the government, inflate tenders and contracts, get kickbacks from awarding tenders, granting media companies advertisements, dodge taxes, lie to their landlords and creditors and in total live out the Ugandan way of corruption, defaulting on everything. The economy upcountry has been eroded, leaving Kampala as the only centre of any meaningful commercial activity. And in Kampala, the construction and growth of the last 28 years has been what the Bible terms pouring new wine into old wineskins. Rather than expand or re-design the city, every 100 square metres of land in Kampala is now being built upon, encroached on, luxury hotels, office buildings and private homes forced onto the old infrastructure and neighbourhoods.Kololo is now more commercial district than residential area, as is Nakasero and Bugolobi. A former residential house becomes a bar or computer training firm, and so cars park along the roadside, blocking public traffic. Kampala has turned into a city without any plan and even important embassies like the American, Swiss and others essentially are located in slum areas. There is not a single square kilometre in Kampala where everything works fully --- street lights, drainage, piped water, roads and garbage management. At least one or more of these has a problem. Many people who live in parts of Jinja, Mbarara, Fort Portal, Entebbe and Masaka towns, if they have corporate jobs or stable businesses actually live a much better quality of life than the vast majority of Kampala's residents. Politically, the last 28 years have seen Uganda regress to the old feudal ways of the pre-colonial era. The government is now located in State House, a clearing place for wheeler-dealers, political hangers-on and sycophants.With everything falling apart, a sarcastic joke has taken root from the real cries of desperate Ugandans: "Tusaba Gavumenti...", meaning "We call upon the government..." or "We request the government..." to do this or that for us or help us in our desperation. A certain amount of freedom has taken root in Uganda since 1986 but as most of us are now discovering, not the kind of freedom that is beneficial to a nation. On one hand, the President, Parliament, government, police and army can be criticised without too much fear of consequences most of the time, which is an unquestionable positive. But on the other, the section of Ugandan public life on which much depends --- the corporate community --- is one very few dare criticise. So we have an odd situation in which the head of state can be called names on radio and TV, but the marketing manager of a beer or telecoms company is above criticism because then the advertisement lifeblood of the media, the "fourth estate" and crucial watchdog on the public's behalf, will be drained away. Secondly, and most troubling, the laws of Uganda are strictly enforced mainly when an offender or suspect is thought to threaten the President's hold on power through organising a serious opposition party, plotting a military coup or armed rebellion or exposing sensitive secrets of State House. Short of that, anything goes. We can drive without seatbelts, drive both on the left and right sides of the road, forge academic certificates, build on wetlands, evade taxes, bribe magistrates, immigration and licencing officials, import and sell expired and sub-standard goods and life goes on. As a result of this, all standards have dropped. The cost of doing business is high, partly because of the bribes and the burden that comes with fraud. That is why Ugandan companies cannot expand beyond Uganda into other environments that will not tolerate our level of bribery and cutting corners. The worst damage inflicted on Uganda by the NRM has been to destroy the sacredness and prestige of institutions. The public and our growing children now regard a minister or MP as no more dignified and honourable than a boda boda rider, a judge or magistrate much the same way as a money-changing conman. The ability to and importance of working and thinking incrementally in terms of 1-2-3-4-5 step-by-step has been replaced by the impatience to have it all at once and immediately. A 22-year-old just out of university feels "poor" if he does not own a fully-furnished house by the age of 24 and a personal house by 28. The idea of working for the long-term has ceased to feel like an honour and call of duty.This is the NRM legacy, of primitive feudal rule, institutionalised corruption, of people with Masters' degrees acting like common criminals, and a lack of dedication in everything we do, that will be with Uganda for decades to come.

TITLE: Corruption at Immigration will not stall the national ID project
SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION (92%); NATIONAL IDENTITY CARDS (92%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); IDENTITY SECURITY (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (89%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); CITIZENSHIP (78%); NATIONAL SECURITY (73%); WRITERS (71%); COUNTERFEITING (71%)
TEXT: The Sunday Monitor of March 23 carried a misleading article regarding the national identity card project currently under implementation under the coordination of Ministry of Internal Affairs. We wish to share facts on this very important exercise. For a while, Ugandans have decried the poor service delivery at the Directorate of Immigration - stolen visa money, missing/stolen passports, passport forgeries, slow delivery, congestion and poor services at the department and non-Ugandans being issued with our passports. As part of the need to improve the situation, two regional Immigration offices were opened in Mbale and Mbarara and more will be opened. But as part of deeper solutions to what is obviously a deeper problem, the Minister of Internal Affairs, Gen Aronda Nyakairima, had to give policy direction and guidance. He constituted an inquiry into the corruption, mismanagement and abuse of office at the Department of Citizenship and Immigration. Through the Sunday Monitor article by Chris Obore, you see an attempt to divert the probe into corruption at Immigration under a different guise. The findings of this probe will be made public is in no way related to the identity card project as the Sunday Monitor story alleges. Again, Mr Obore alleges that there is a power struggle to control the "more than Shs280 billion to be spent in the issuance of the national identity cards". While indeed the director of Citizenship and Immigration, Mr Godfrey Sasagah, is the accounting officer to National Security Information System Account (ID project account), it is unfair and unjust to insinuate of a fight where the Permanent Secretary, Dr SP Kagoda, has previously written to the Finance ministry in support of the director as accounting officer! This is diversionary because all implementing agencies  of the project have a stake in its successful implementation under the  watchful eye of Finance ministry.  The writer only needed to ask for these - and more documents to write from an informed point of view. However, the Minister of Internal Affairs would be willing to investigate any issues that threaten policy implementation. Yet again, by his own written admission, that "Gen Aronda reportedly wrote several warnings to Sasagah giving him ultimatums of a few months to stamp out corruption in the directorate",  Obore exposes the power of an existing force behind his article. Obore has previously decried corruption at Immigration, what is clouding his judgment now? Can the fight against corruption be handled with kid gloves? Has the department of Immigration performed to Uganda's full expectations? Did the previous ID project successfully take off under the Directorate of Immigration? Hadn't it stalled because of lack of direction until the idea to implement it under a multi-sectoral approach was mooted as the only right policy intervention, where different stakeholders are now involved? If there are any lessons from the previous pilot project, it is those lessons that we draw experiences from to make sure the unique identification of citizens is duly done. Gen Nyakairima and the entire work team will not compromise on values of the project - accountability, integrity, accuracy and security in anyway. The national identity card project is on course and we are more than determined to deliver as promised under the uniqueness of the multi-sectoral approach of the key agencies - UBOS, the Electoral Commission, Uganda Registration Services Bureau, Directorate of Citizenship and Immigration, Uganda Bureau of Statistics and National Information Technology-Uganda. From the lowest officer to the Cabinet and the President, it is more than a duty, more than an obligation, more than responsibility; it is a response to national honour. We appeal to Ugandans to turn up in large numbers to enroll for their identity cards at their nearest parish on April 14. Ms Ankunda is a communications officer, Ministry of  Internal Affairs. pankunda@gmail.com

TITLE: There is no quick solution to corruption - Mbabazi
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (77%); CIVIL SERVICES (75%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (71%); WAGES & SALARIES (66%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (50%)
TEXT: Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi has said there is no quick solution to corruption. He said this while launching the Action for Transparency project (A4T) at the Wakiso District headquarters on Friday. Wakiso Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi has said there is no quick solution to corruption. He said this while launching the Action for Transparency project (A4T) at the Wakiso District headquarters on Friday. Mr Mbabazi said fighting corruption will require more than just the good institutional and legal framework that government has put in place. He said the fight will require more determination, commitment and patience, calling on members of the public to support all government efforts against corruption."I hear people who think that we can decree today that let there be no corruption and there will be no corruption tomorrow, it doesn't work like that," Mr Mbabazi said. Mr Mbabazi said Action for Transparency Project is to enhance government efforts in fighting corruption. While delivering his speech, the Swedish Ambassador to Uganda, Mr Anders Urban Anderson, said making budgets readily available to the public will improve efficiency and transparency in service delivery. However, the Wakiso District chairperson, Mr Matia Lwanga Bwanika, said unless government improves salaries of civil servants like teachers and medical workers, the fight against corruption will not yield much. The awareness campaign is aimed at fighting corruption and mismanagement of public funds for schools and health centres in Wakiso, Kampala and Mukono districts through enhanced citizens participation in monitoring of budgets. Using a mobile phone or a computer with internet, anyone will be able to check the amount of government money allocated to each public primary school and public health centres in the named districts and how much was spent. bjumbe@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Punish drunk health workers, anti-corruption monitors appeal
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ARRESTS (89%); TAXES & TAXATION (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); TALKS & MEETINGS (71%)
TEXT: Mr Benson Okong, the LC3 chairperson, confirmed some health workers had been reporting on duty while drunk, adding that he has contacted police to arrest any health staff going to work while drunk. Nakapiripirit-  Anti-corruption monitors in Nabilatuk Sub-county in Nakapiripirit District have called for tougher penalties on health workers who report to work drunk. The group made the appeal on Monday while presenting their findings on corruption at the meeting supported by Anti-Corruption Coalition of Uganda, a civil society organisation. "The rate of drunkardness among the health staff, especially those working at Nabilatuk Health Centre IV is worrying. It is also corruption because they are paid by government using taxpayers' money yet they are not delivering quality services to the people who pay taxes," Mr John Korobe, the anti-corruption field monitor of Narengeshep Parish, said. Ms Pauline Anias, a community corruption monitor leader from Natopojo Parish, said the vice was keeping patients away from the health facility because the nurses are rude to patients due to the influence of alcohol. "Sometimes they even reach the extent of chasing away patients that they are dirty," Ms Anias added. The monitors also questioned the speed at which drugs get finished, forcing patients to buy them from clinics. Sr Jane Titin, the acting in-charge of the facility, admitted there were some workers who were reporting to work while drunk but added that they stopped the habit after the administration cautioned them. On chasing away patients, Sr Titin said: "No patient has been chased from the facility because of dirtiness." Mr Benson Okong, the LC3 chairperson, confirmed some health workers had been reporting on duty while drunk, adding that he has contacted police to arrest any health staff going to work while drunk. Mr Okong also faulted the National Medical Stores (NMS) for supplying few drugs to the health centre.
